column3: Writing the plot of a perfect tragedy is more complex than one might think.  The ideal tragedy should "imitate actions that excite pity and fear. " (paragraph 2) You don't simply want the story to shock the reader. The other important aspects are what tragic events happen and who the events happen to. If you had a successful good man whose fortune changed suddenly for the worse and the man was brought down into misfortune. This would not inspire fear or pity but only shock the reader. Same with a downfall of a terrible villain because it would satisfy the reader instead of making them feel pity.  The best tragedy is written about fortune going from good to bad due to a great error of judgment or frailty.
column4: Writing a tragedy is no small feat that requires a depth of understanding and expertise. A tragedy should be designed to elicit both feelings of pity and fear, rather than just shocking the reader. The core of a tragedy lies not only in the events that occur but also in the characters involved and the way they are affected by those events. A tragedy should illustrate the plight of a protagonist whose fortune took a sudden and drastic turn, or how a bad villain's downfall can make the reader feel indifferent rather than inspire compassion.

column3: The most important rule of an ideal tragedy is that it must evoke specific emotions in the audience based on their perception of the characters. The audience must feel pity for the main character, because they don't deserve all the bad things that happen to them, but they must also feel fear because they relate to some of the main character's flaws and are afraid that this tragedy will happen in their own lives. A second rule states that the main character must not be a completely good or evil man, but a man who has a few small flaws that lead to disaster. Another very important rule is that the events of the play must progress from good to bad, and it must end terribly for the main character so that those emotions mentioned in rule one are felt clearly. If the main character walks off the stage unscathed, this is definitely not an ideal tragedy and more like a comedy, according to Aristotle.
column4: The essence of an ideal tragedy lies in eliciting distinct emotions in the audience based on their interpretation of the characters and their fates. The central character must evoke a sense of pity, balancing fear of facing similar circumstances with recognition of the protagonist's flaws leading to ultimate misfortune. Tragedy unfolds with a progression of escalating challenges, culminating in a tragic conclusion for the protagonist. A man with a few flaws, but whose flaws ultimately contribute to his downfall, rather than defining his character, can serve as a vehicle for tragedy.

column3: Three elements of an ideal tragedy as described by Aristotle are a well constructed plot, a character's soul, as well as the production/performance. The most important element of an ideal tragedy is based off of the plot. Aristotle says that, " The change of fortune should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad," (Aristotle, 3). The outcome of the main character will have come from some sort of great error or frailty, the ideal tragic hero should be an all good man with a very minor flaw in his character, and the entire tragedy should be continued upon this judgement. Aristotle also explains how a the plot should be a very complex plan where the actions of the characters exemplify emotions such as pity and fear with the distinctive mark of tragic imitation. He suggests that the best sorts of a tragedy are the complex plots that arouse both pity and fear. He then explains how a good plot must avoid a hero becomming miserable, avoid the transition from misery to happiness for an the antagonist, and also avoid the antagonist to feel happiness and leading into one's misery. He simply just believes that the best plot derives from the mistrtune of someone and whose future downfall leads to an error in judgement. The second element includes the character's actions and personality. To Aristotle, the character must be set up for failure even though this character has the personality of a "good character." The show , "follows plainly, in the first place, that the change of fortune presented must not be the spectacle of a virtuous man brought from prosperity to adversity: for this moves neither pity nor fear; it merely shocks us. Nor, again, that of a bad man passing from adversity to prosperity: for nothing can be more alien to the spirit of Tragedy; it possesses no single tragic quality; it neither satisfies the moral sense nor calls forth pity or fear," (Aristotle, 2).  Meaning this, the overall sense and focus of the play should not be based on the hero losing his "good." Instead, the character must make multiple judgements and go through an entire storyline, not aware of the downfall set right for him. The final element of an ideal tragedy is the spectacle and production itself. Although Aristotle does not go fully into the details regarding this element, in paragraph 3, it is noted that " A tragedy, then, to be perfect according to the rules of art, should be of this construction....because he follows this principle in his plays, many of which end unhappily. It is, as we have said, the right ending. The best proof is that on the stage and in dramatic competition, such plays, if well worked out, are the most tragic in effect" (Aristotle, 3). Rather than explaining the scenic visuals of the play and visual effects of a "spectacle," Aristotle explains that the true spectacle is the dramatic competition and the tragedy in effect. The best endings is one that is unhappy and shocks the audience.
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  An ideal tragedy, according to Aristotle, is a story with a compelling plot, a morally flawed character, and a captivating performance. To achieve a tragic effect, Aristotle emphasizes the importance of reversing fortune from good to bad.  The tragic hero should be someone with a minor flaw in their personality, setting them up for failure, and then subjecting them to a series of misfortunes. A tragedy should also have a complex plot with well-developed characters and a sense of emotional intensity.  The plot should avoid portraying the hero's transformation from good to evil or the antagonist feeling happiness at the expense of their downfall. It should also avoid the tragedy falling into the trap of simple or predictable elements.  The focus should not be on the hero's happiness or misery, but on the cascading consequences of their actions. The best tragedy ends with a sense of tragedy and shock rather than a resolution of a conflict.

column3: The vizier made sure that taxes were collected. Scribes would work with the vizier and they kept government records. They could read and write which in the time, was a rare skill and they had mastered it (The Chain Of Command Section). Only nobles could hold government posts, in the social pyramid, they were right below the pharaoh (along with priests). They profited from tributes in these positions. Nobles had great status and grew very wealthy from the donations to the gods (Noble Aims Section). Soldiers fought in wars or put an end to domestic uprisings. They also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved with building structures like pyramids and palaces during long periods of time. Physicians and craftsmen and woman made up the middle class. Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and much more. Merchants and storekeepers would sell these goods to the people (Soldier On Section). Now on the bottom of the social pyramid (or social structure as it is called in the article), slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. They were forced to work on building projects. They also worked extremely hard at the discretion of the pharoh or nobles. Wanting to change your social status was impossible to do. A very tiny number of peasants and farmers did go up in the economic ladder. Schools were ran by priests and artisans. Boys who could read and write would become scribes and would go into working for the government (The Bottom Of The Heap Section). That is pretty much all that was to be said for the different social classes in the government.
column4: The government relied heavily on the cooperation of scribes who meticulously documented tax revenue and maintained official records. Literacy was uncommon among the general population, and scribes possessed a valuable skill that allowed them to read, write, and carry out their duties.  Nobles, the highest-ranking members of society, held significant government positions. They collected taxes and protected the nation in military undertakings. They enriched themselves through tributes and donations to the gods, allowing them to maintain their high standing.  Soldiers were the backbone of the army, carrying out tasks and fighting in various situations. They were also responsible for monitoring and overseeing the peasants, farmers, and slaves involved in construction projects.  The middle class, comprising craftsmen, physicians, and artists, played a crucial role. Craftsmen produced and sold jewelry, pottery, tools, and various other products. Merchants and storekeepers also played a significant role in connecting the people with the goods and services they needed.  The lowest social class, comprising slaves, became victims of war and human exploitation. Forced to work on building projects, they were subjected to harsh conditions and inhumane treatment. The government was powerless to provide them with any form of social mobility.  It was highly uncommon for individuals from lower socioeconomic backgrounds to rise to positions of power in the government. While a few skilled peasants and farmers managed to climb the social ladder, education and wealth

column3: in a meat factory during 1906 the workers did their best they can to use every piece of meat. including the spoiled ones that had already gone bad. they had many different  ideas for covering up the odor or the mold on the meat.  in paragraph one it says they would chop it up into sausage.  another way to cover up the meat was, as stated in paragraph 2 "meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters". also when they would  get really bad they would put the meat in a stronger pickle which destoyed the odor. they would call this process as giving them a thrity per cent. and another really stange way of taking care of the spoiled meat as they said in paragraph 3 " there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white – it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption." in conclusion these meat factories had various way of being able to still use spoiled meat.
column4: Sure, here is the reworded passage:  In 1906, the workers in a meat factory were faced with the challenge of utilizing every piece of meat available to them, including spoiled items that had gone rotten. They weren't interested in wasting any of the meat, so they devised several ingenious ways to cover up its odor or mold.  One technique they used was to chop up the spoiled meat into sausage and sell it as quality food. Another method that they employed was to take out meat that had been previously in pickle, rub it with soda, and then sell it as free-lunch food. When things got really bad, they would use a stronger pickle to cover up the stench, calling it a "thiry per cent." Another peculiar approach was to use old sausage as a source of fresh meat, which was then dosed with borax and glycerin and then reintroduced into the production cycle.  These makeshift methods allowed the workers to reuse spoiled meat while still preserving its quality and availability to those who could afford it.

column3: The social structure of Egypt was built like a pyramid. At the bottom of the social structures, slaves would be forced  to work on building projects, and Farmers tended the field, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. In the middle of the social structure were the Viziers, who ensured that taxes were collected.

column3: According to Aristotle, the ideal tragedy has a morally neutral protagonist, a negative change in fortune caused by weakness or error, and an ending which does not see the complete victory of the protagonist. The first element is essential because it creates an everyman which the audience can empathize with easily, and therefore feel pity for. The change in fortune must be negative because otherwise the story becomes happy rather than tragic. Finally, the protagonist must not win completely against the villain, because this creates too satisfying an ending.
column4: According to Aristotle, a good tragedy should feature a protagonist who is neutral in terms of morality, and their fortunes should change negatively due to either weakness or a flawed decision. The play should conclude with the protagonist's defeat. Another element of an ideal tragedy is that it elicts feelings of pity and fear from the audience in response to the characters/events. column3: Throughout Chapter 13, Aristotle proclaims three elements of an ideal tragedy must be the virtuous character, the flaws within that character's personality, and the shift of ending into one of misfortune.  Aristotle overall scopes the plot of perfect tragedy by revealing that the  character must be one of prestige. In his efforts to indicate this claim, he incorporates the examples of  Oediupus and Thyestes. In doing this, Aristotle indicates that one of the key features of an ideal tragedy involves an individual that is highly prosperous in order to drive his plot even further. The second element expressed is the trait within a character that allows for a downfall. Aristotle also used Oedipus, Orestes, and other tragic heroes from mythology in order to heavily emphasize that the flaw in the personality. Aristotle mentions that this error in one's character should be due to misjudgment or frailty. Evidently, all these elements influence the overall idea he expressed that to a perfect tragedy an individual must experience a downfall or a reversal of misfortune. He uses the previous two elements in order to enhance this idea by affirming that from being a prosperous individual, the character's flaws will allow him to plunder into a downfall and lose the  fortune they possess.
column4: Aristotle's treatise on tragedy emphasizes three key elements. These elements include the virtuous character, the flaws within the character's personality, and the shift of ending into misfortune. He illustrates these elements by analyzing the stories of Oedipus and Thyestes. Furthermore, Aristotle emphasizes the importance of wealth and luxuriousness in a tragedy, as this can greatly contribute to a character's downfall. Additionally, he uses numerous tragic heroes from mythology to illustrate the importance of one's flaws and how this can lead to a tragic downfall.

column4: A tragic story should evoke a mix of feelings in the audience, including feelings of pity for the protagonist and conflicting feelings of fear about what the antagonist might do next. A tragedy with a protagonist with a clear plan and means for achieving their goals is unlikely to be as emotionally resonant. This is because it does not allow the audience to experience the suspense and fear that arises from having to wonder how the protagonist will overcome their obstacles.  A tragedy's power lies in the ability to create a cycle of pity and fear,

column3: In p1, it said that the egyptian society was structured like a pyramid, the top were the strongest and ones in charge and the lower you got the less "important" you were. Thats just my take on that. In each section of the pyramid however, there was a class. And each of these classes had different purposes and jobs. At the top were the pharaohs, believed to be gods in human form according to p3. In the second section you have nobles and priests according to p7. Now third, im asumming is the soldiers. Fourth were slaves and farmers, basically the citizens.
column4: The ancient Egyptian society had a hierarchical structure that resembled a pyramid. The top, comprising high-ranking individuals, held significant authority. Moving down, each class had distinct responsibilities and roles. Notably, the pharaohs were believed to be deities in human form, while the nobles and priests occupied positions of influence. Third, the military, composed of soldiers and farmers, formed the lower echelons of society.

column3:
The Egyptian social structure was shaped like a pyramid, the bottom of the pyramid (social structure) being the poorest people. This included Slaves and farmers. "Farmers paid taxes that could amount to as much as 60% of their yearly harvest" (Paragraph 12). The middle of the pyramid is comparable to most average people today- living comfortably, but not rolling in money. These people were priests and nobles. "Nobles enjoyed great status and also grew wealthy from donations to the gods"(paragraph 7). And now last but definitely not least,  
"The upper class"... This consists of gods, Shuch as Ra, Osiris, and Isis. Pharaohs were also in the upper class. "The Egyptians also elevated some human beings to gods. Their leaders, called pharaohs, were believed to be gods in human form"(paragraph 2). The Egyptian social hierarchy is simple but complicated at the same time.
column4: The Egyptian social structure was a hierarchical pyramid, with the bottom of the pyramid consisting of the poorest people. Farmers paid taxes that amounted to half or even more of their yearly harvest, while priests and nobles lived more comfortably. The upper class consisted of gods and high-ranking officials, with Pharaohs holding a special place in society.

column3: The factory would use chemicals to mask the smell of spoiled meet, pickle spoiled meet, and insert hot rods instead of the bones into certain cuts. The author describes how workers "would rub it up with soda to take away the smell." Factory workers would also "insert in the hole a white-hot iron" into the ham or other meat to take away the rotting and attempt to preserve it. Meat factories were disgusting places that did many unsanitary and unsafe things.
column4: The factory used chemicals to conceal the offensive odors of spoiled meat, spoiled pickle, and inserted hot rods in specific areas. The author detailed the methods used by workers to remove these odors and preserve the meat. Meat factories were known for unsanitary and unsafe practices.

column3: They were the pharaoh, that the ancient Egyptians looked at as gods and put in control. The text states, "Because the people of Egypt believed that their pharaohs were gods, they entrusted their rulers with many responsibilities." They created the temple to worship the gods and built stone pyramids in honor of the gods when they die. The text states, "After pharaohs died, huge stone pyramids were built as their tombs."
column4: The ancient Egyptians revered their pharaohs as gods, granting them immense power and control. Their unwavering belief in the divine authority of their pharaohs emphasized their responsibilities to the people, hence resulting in the establishment of religious structures and monumental structures to honor and commemorate the gods after their demise.

column3: Different social classes are involved in this government. Social class is a set of concepts in social sciences and political theory centered on models of social stratification. People with a lower class have a lower sense of access to public services and have lower satisfaction.
